title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly identify the intermolecular forces in both compounds.

· Compound L – dispersion forces, dipole-dipole forces, and hydrogen bonding

· Compound Z – dispersion forces and dipole-dipole forces

The response correctly identifies the intermolecular forces in both compounds.

· Compound L – dispersion forces, dipole-dipole forces, and hydrogen bonding

· Compound Z – dispersion forces and dipole-dipole forces

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide both the correct explanation equivalent to the following.

· The boiling point of compound L is higher than that of compound Z because the intermolecular attractions in compound L are greater. The strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding in compound L, which is not present in compound Z, account for the overall stronger intermolecular attractions in compound L. Stronger attractions require more energy to be overcome, so compound L has the higher boiling point.

The response provides a correct explanation equivalent to the following.

· The boiling point of compound L is higher than that of compound Z because the intermolecular attractions in compound L are greater. The strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding in compound L, which is not present in compound Z, account for the overall stronger intermolecular attractions in compound L. Stronger attractions require more energy to be overcome, so compound L has the higher boiling point.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide both the correct answer and a valid justification equivalent to the following.

· No. The linear relationship between ln  [ C 2 H 6 O] MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43FD@ versus time is consistent with a first-order reaction, but the slope of the line does not indicate a rate constant of − 0 .50 min −1 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4387@ . The slope of the line is − 0 .20 min −1 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4384@ which corresponds to a rate constant of − 0 .20 min −1 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4384@ , since slope=− k MathType@MTEF@5@5@@421B@ for a first-order process.
